RISK MANAGEMENT PLAN 2004

EXECUTIVE SUMMARY AND DATA ELEMENTS PACKAGE

CITY OF BENICIA WATER TREATMENT PLANT
100 WATER WAY
BENICIA, CALIFORNIA 94510

1.0 Background Data
In accordance with Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations, Chapter 68 (40 CFR 68), promulgated by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) and Article2, Chapter 6.95 of the California Health and Safety Code (HSC), the City of Benicia (Benicia) submits this Risk Management Plan (RMP) for operations at their Water Treatment Plant (WTP) in Benicia, California.  Benicia provides potable water to their service area, which coincides with the city limits.  The facility is capable of treating 12 million gallons per day of water.
2.0 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policy
Benicia is committed to protecting the health and safety of its employees, the surrounding community, and the environment; therefore, it is Benicia's policy to manage a safe and healthy workplace, protect the environment and maintain compliance with safety, health, and environmental regulations: Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP), 40 CFR 68; OSHA Process Safety Management (PSM), 29 CFR Part 1910.119; and California Accidental Release Prevention (CalARP) Program, 29 CCR, Title 19, Division 2, Chapter 4.5.  This commitment is demonstrated by the comprehensive accidental release prevention program that covers areas such as design, installation, operating procedures, maintenance, and employee training associated with the processes at the facility.  It is the policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of regulated substances.
2.1 Stationary Sources and Regulated Substances
Benicia is subject to the Federal Risk Management Plan (RMP) program because chlorine, a regulated substance, is present at the facility in amounts greater than 2,500 pounds.  Benicia is required to treat the water supply so that it meets or exceeds the drinking water quality standards of the California Department of Healt

h Services.  Benicia uses chlorine to disinfect the water.  Benicia's chlorine disinfection process consists of one-ton chlorine cylinders, a containment vessel, chlorinators, and a piping system that is all under vacuum.  The process and storage cylinders can contain a maximum amount of 8,000 pounds of chlorine.
2.2 Worst-Case and Alternative-Case Release Scenario
This section has been deleted to comply with 2004 regulatory updates to address homeland security.  Information regarding the Offsite Consequence Analysis is located with the Superintendent at the City of Benicia, Water Treatment Plant.
3.0 General Accidental Release Prevention Program and Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps
The facility has taken all the necessary steps to comply with the accidental release prevention program requirements set out under 40 CFR Part 68 of the EPA.  The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program that is in place at the stationary source.
3.1 Process Safety Information
Benicia Water Treatment Plant maintains a detailed record of safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes.
3.2 Process Hazard Analysis
Benicia has conducted comprehensive studies to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled efficiently.  The methodology used to carry out these analyses is a Checklist.  Any findings related to the hazard analysis are addressed in a timely manner.  The most recent PHA/update was performed on August 24, 2004.
3.3 Operating Procedures
For the purposes of safely conducting activities within the covered process, Benicia Water Treatment Plant maintains written operating procedures.  These procedures address various modes of operation such as initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, normal shutdown and startup after a turnaround.  The information is regularly reviewed an

d is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.  Operating Procedures are reviewed annually for accuracy and pertinence.
3.4 Training
Benicia Water Treatment Plant has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the processes are competent in the operating procedures associated with these processes.  Refresher training is provided at least every year and more frequently as needed.
3.5 Mechanical Integrity
Benicia Water Treatment Plant carries out documented maintenance checks on process equipment to ensure proper operations.  Process equipment examined by these checks includes among others; containment vessel, one-ton chlorine cylinders, piping systems, relief and vent systems, leak detectors and controls.  Maintenance operations are carried out by qualified personnel with previous training in maintenance practices.  Furthermore, these personnel are offered specialized training as needed.  Any equipment deficiencies identified by the maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.  Mechanical Integrity checks are conducted during chlorine change out and one-ton chlorine delivery.
3.6 Management of Change
Written procedures are in place at Benicia Water Treatment Plant to manage changes in process chemicals, technology, equipment and procedures.  The most recent review/revision of management of change procedures was performed on June 10, 1999.  Process operators, maintenance personnel or any other employee whose job tasks are affected by a modification in process conditions are promptly made aware of and offered training to deal with the modification.  An update to the Management of Change is expected to be completed by October 31, 2004 as part of the update to the Process Safety Management.
3.7 Pre-startup Reviews
Pre-start up safety reviews related to new processes and to modifications in established processes are conducted as a regular practice at Benicia Water Treatment Plant.  The most recent review was pe

rformed on June 8, 1999.  These reviews are conducted to confirm that construction, equipment, operating and maintenance procedures are suitable for safe startup prior to placing equipment into operation.  An update to the Management of Change is expected to be completed by October 31, 2004 as part of the update to the Process Safety Management.
3.8 Compliance Audits
Benicia Water Treatment Plant conducts audits on a regular basis to determine whether the provisions set out under the RMP rule are being implemented.  The most recent compliance audit was conducted on November 19, 2003.  Any corrective actions required as a result of the triennial audits are undertaken in a safe and prompt manner.  This audit is located in the Risk Management Plan Inspection Report. 
3.9 Incident Investigation
Benicia Water Treatment Plant promptly investigates any incident that has resulted in, or could reasonably result in a catastrophic release of a regulated substance.  These investigations are undertaken to identify the situation leading to the incident as well as any corrective actions to prevent the release from reoccurring.  All reports are retained for a minimum of 5 years.
3.10 Employee Participation
Benicia Water Treatment Plant truly believes that process safety management and accident prevention is a team effort.  Agency employees are strongly encouraged to express their views concerning accident prevention issues and to recommend improvements.  In addition, the employees have access to all information created as part of the facility's implementation of the regulations, including information resulting from process hazard analyses in particular.
3.11 Contractors
On occasion, Benicia hires contractors to conduct specialized maintenance and construction activities.  Benicia Water Treatment Plant has a strict policy of informing the contractors of known potential hazards related to the contractor's work and the processes.  Contractors are also informed of all the procedures fo

r emergency response should an accidental release of a regulated substance occur.
3.12 Five-year Accident History
Benicia Water Treatment Plant has had an excellent record of preventing accidental releases over the last 5 years.  Due to Benicia?s stringent release prevention policies, there has been no accidental release during this period that caused any onsite death, injury or significant property damage, or known offsite death, injury, property damage, environmental damage, evacuations, or sheltering in place.
3.13 Emergency Response Plan
Benicia Water Treatment Plant carries a written emergency response plan to deal with accidental releases of hazardous materials.  The plan includes all aspects of emergency response including adequate first aid and medical treatment, evacuations, notification of local emergency response agencies and the public, as well as post-incident decontamination of affected areas.  To ensure proper functioning, the emergency response equipment is regularly inspected and serviced.  In addition, the plan is promptly updated to reflect any pertinent changes taking place within the processes that would require a modified emergency response.  As part of the Bioterrorism Act of 2002, the Emergency Response Plan is being updated and is expected to be completed by December 31, 2004.
4.0 FOR MORE INFORMATION

Benicia recognizes that some persons may be interested in obtaining more detailed information regarding the CalARP RMP prevention program components not discussed herein.
